content.title: Bell Palsy
content.summary: Acute idiopathic unilateral peripheral facial nerve (CN VII) paralysis of presumed viral etiology, characterized by sudden onset of facial weakness affecting all facial muscle groups on one side
key_points: Most common cause of acute unilateral facial paralysis (70% of cases)
Affects upper AND lower face (peripheral vs central pattern)
70% complete recovery without treatment; 85% with steroids

statement.text: Bell palsy is an acute idiopathic peripheral facial nerve (CN VII) palsy resulting in unilateral facial weakness affecting both upper and lower facial muscles. It is the most common cause of acute facial paralysis, presumed to be caused by herpes simplex virus reactivation in the geniculate ganglion. Early treatment with corticosteroids within 72 hours of onset significantly improves complete recovery rates. The prognosis is generally favorable with 70% achieving complete recovery spontaneously and 85% with steroid treatment.
statement.formal: Bell Palsy = Acute unilateral facial weakness (upper + lower) + No identifiable cause + Exclusion of central lesion

explanation.intuition: The facial nerve takes a long, winding path through a narrow bony canal in the skull (the facial canal). When the nerve swells - likely from viral reactivation - it gets compressed within this tight space, leading to dysfunction. Understanding that it's a peripheral nerve problem explains why the entire side of the face is weak (forehead included), unlike strokes which spare the forehead due to bilateral cortical innervation of upper facial muscles.
explanation.key_insight: The critical clinical distinction is upper vs lower motor neuron facial weakness. In Bell palsy (LMN), the entire hemifacial weakness occurs because the facial nerve directly innervates all ipsilateral facial muscles. In central (UMN) lesions like stroke, the forehead is spared because the forehead muscles receive bilateral cortical input, so the contralateral hemisphere can compensate.
explanation.technical_details: The facial nerve carries motor fibers to facial muscles, parasympathetic fibers to lacrimal and salivary glands (via greater petrosal and chorda tympani), special sensory fibers for taste from anterior 2/3 of tongue (chorda tympani), and general sensory from external auditory canal. Depending on lesion location within the facial canal, patients may have hyperacusis (stapedius weakness), decreased lacrimation, or taste disturbance in addition to facial weakness.

definitions_glossary.bell_palsy: Acute idiopathic peripheral facial nerve palsy causing unilateral facial weakness of sudden onset
definitions_glossary.facial_nerve: Cranial nerve VII carrying motor, sensory, and parasympathetic fibers; controls facial expression
definitions_glossary.peripheral_facial_palsy: Weakness affecting entire hemifacial, including forehead, due to lesion of facial nerve itself
definitions_glossary.central_facial_palsy: Weakness affecting lower face only with forehead sparing, due to lesion above facial nucleus
definitions_glossary.house_brackmann_scale: Six-grade clinical scale for assessing facial nerve function from normal (I) to total paralysis (VI)
definitions_glossary.geniculate_ganglion: Sensory ganglion of facial nerve located in facial canal, site of HSV-1 latency
definitions_glossary.bells_phenomenon: Upward and outward eye movement when attempting to close eyes, visible in facial palsy
definitions_glossary.synkinesis: Abnormal simultaneous movements (e.g., mouth twitching when blinking) from aberrant nerve regeneration
definitions_glossary.ramsay_hunt_syndrome: Facial palsy with vesicular rash in ear canal, caused by varicella zoster virus reactivation
definitions_glossary.chorda_tympani: Branch of facial nerve carrying taste from anterior 2/3 of tongue
definitions_glossary.stapedius_muscle: Small muscle innervated by facial nerve; dysfunction causes hyperacusis
definitions_glossary.lagophthalmos: Inability to fully close the eyelid, complication requiring eye protection
definitions_glossary.crocodile_tears: Gustatory lacrimation from aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibers

pathophysiology.mechanism: Bell palsy is believed to result from reactivation of herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) latent in the geniculate ganglion. Viral reactivation causes inflammation and edema of the facial nerve within the narrow fallopian canal, leading to nerve compression, ischemia, and demyelination. The degree of axonal degeneration determines prognosis.
anatomical_course: Geniculate ganglion (gives off greater petrosal nerve)
Tympanic segment (gives off nerve to stapedius)
Parotid gland (gives terminal branches to facial muscles)

nerve_injury_grades.neurapraxia: Focal demyelination, no axonal loss, complete recovery expected in weeks
nerve_injury_grades.axonotmesis: Axonal disruption with intact endoneurium, regeneration possible at 1mm/day
nerve_injury_grades.neurotmesis: Complete nerve disruption, poor recovery without surgical repair

clinical_features.onset: Acute (hours to 1-3 days), reaching maximum weakness within 3 weeks
clinical_features.weakness_pattern: Unilateral involvement of upper AND lower face (peripheral pattern)

diagnosis_of_exclusion.required: No identifiable cause after clinical evaluation
red_flags_requiring_workup: Signs of malignancy or systemic illness

house_brackmann_grading.grade_II: Slight weakness noticeable on close inspection
house_brackmann_grading.grade_III: Obvious but not disfiguring weakness; complete eye closure with effort
house_brackmann_grading.grade_IV: Obvious disfiguring weakness; incomplete eye closure

corticosteroids.indication: All patients presenting within 72 hours of onset
corticosteroids.regimen: Prednisone 60-80 mg daily for 5-7 days, then taper
corticosteroids.evidence: NNT ~6 for complete recovery at 9 months

antivirals.role: Controversial; may add benefit in severe cases
antivirals.regimen: Valacyclovir 1g TID for 7 days (if used, combine with steroids)
antivirals.evidence: Uncertain additional benefit beyond steroids alone

measures: Moisture chamber or tape eyelid closed

surgical.indication: Rarely indicated; complete denervation with no recovery at 3 months
surgical.options: Facial nerve decompression, facial reanimation procedures

definition.@value: Acute idiopathic unilateral peripheral facial nerve paralysis presumed secondary to viral inflammation, characterized by sudden-onset weakness of all ipsilateral facial muscles

skos.scopeNote: Excludes secondary causes of facial palsy (Ramsay Hunt, Lyme, stroke, tumor); focuses on idiopathic Bell palsy diagnosis and management
skos.example: A 45-year-old man presents with sudden right facial drooping noticed on waking, unable to close right eye or smile symmetrically, with retroauricular pain; examination shows flattened right nasolabial fold AND loss of right forehead wrinkles (peripheral pattern)

learning_objectives: Differentiate peripheral (LMN) from central (UMN) facial weakness
Recognize clinical features and diagnostic criteria for Bell palsy
Initiate appropriate treatment with corticosteroids within 72 hours
Identify red flags requiring additional workup
Implement eye protection measures to prevent corneal damage
clinical_pearls: Forehead involved = peripheral (Bell palsy); forehead spared = central (stroke)
Start steroids within 72 hours - prednisone 60-80mg/day for 5-7 days
Eye protection is critical - artificial tears, ointment, taping closed at night
Vesicular rash = Ramsay Hunt (VZV) - add valacyclovir, worse prognosis
Bilateral facial weakness is NOT Bell palsy - think Lyme, GBS, sarcoid
Most patients recover completely - 70% without treatment, 85% with steroids

board_yield.usmle_step1: Moderate - facial nerve anatomy, UMN vs LMN distinction

common_misconceptions: Forehead sparing occurs in Bell palsy (false - that's central/stroke pattern)
Antivirals are essential treatment (false - steroids are mainstay; antiviral role uncertain)
MRI is required for diagnosis (false - clinical diagnosis; imaging for atypical features)
Bell palsy is a stroke (false - it's peripheral nerve, not central)

skos:related.skos:note: Differential diagnosis - VZV facial palsy with ear vesicles
Can cause bilateral facial palsy, endemic area consideration
